title: 5 fitness and mental health tips for men
intro: Why is muscle power so important? What do you really need to know about your testosterone levels? What are some free, research-backed tools for managing depression? Brett McKay, founder and editor-in-chief of The Art of Manliness, an independent men's health and lifestyle web magazine, shares top health tips. Whether you identify as a man or not, he says a lot of this advice can help us all live healthier lives.Follow us on Instagram: @nprlifekitSign up for our newsletter here.Have an episode idea or feedback you want to share? Email us at lifekit@npr.orgSupport the show and listen to it sponsor-free by signing up for Life Kit+ at plus.npr.org/lifekit

transcript.author: MARIELLE SEGARRA, HOST
transcript.text: You're listening to LIFE KIT...

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: ...From NPR.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Hey. It's Marielle. Brett McKay has an impressive mustache.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: It looks like the head of a broom - black, maybe a little salt and pepper and, to my eye, an indispensable companion to his eyebrows. He first grew it out for Movember in 2009. That's the annual campaign in November where folks sport mustaches to raise awareness and money for men's health.

transcript.author: BRETT MCKAY
transcript.text: I didn't think I was going to keep it. But at the end of Movember, I was like, you know what? I actually look pretty good in this. And my wife was like, I'm really surprised by this, but I also think you look good in it, too.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Brett is the writer of a blog and the host of a podcast called "The Art Of Manliness." So of course, I had to ask, what does manliness mean to him? He said he studied classical literature in college, things like the "Iliad" and the writings of Cicero. And that word, manliness, meant something different then than it often does today.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: I think today, we have this sort of cartoonish idea of what manliness is. It's this big, burly guy who likes to eat meat and lift weights. But for ancient Greeks and ancient Romans - and you can see this all the way up through the 19th century in the West - to be manly meant the development of certain virtues, like prudence and courage and strength. And so it's about becoming a virtuous, all-around solid dude. And I wanted to bring that idea back that manliness could be something that's positive and affirming.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: "The Art Of Manliness" actually reminds me a lot of LIFE KIT. Brett interviews experts on different topics, including health, but the show is made specifically for men, and they give tips on all sorts of topics, including growing facial hair.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: One is, don't waste your money on beard serums or vitamins that promise increased beard growth. They're probably not going to do it. A lot of facial hair just comes down to genetics. But the thing you can do for facial hair is just, like, be a healthy person, like, sleep well, eat a nutritious diet, exercise, 'cause that also contributes to hair growth.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: On this episode of LIFE KIT, Brett and I talk about men's health. He'll share five takeaways based on the reporting he's done for "The Art Of Manliness" on movement, explosive strength, testosterone, depression and the good stress of socializing. A quick disclaimer here - Brett is not a medical doctor. He's someone who's passionate about his health and about sharing the research out there. If you do have any questions about these topics, for sure bring them up with your doctor.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: You have an episode on how men, and everyone really, can nurture their physical identity. So what does that mean, physical identity?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: So we are moving creatures, right? When we're a baby, we learn how to crawl. Eventually, we learn how to walk, and then when we're kids, we run and play. The problem is you develop this idea when you're a kid - it's like, you're either an athlete or you're not an athlete.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: I'm sure everyone remembers when they were in elementary school or middle school getting picked last for the dodgeball team, playing Little League baseball and just realizing, oh, I'm not good at this. And so what happens is when you're a kid, you're like, well, I'm not an athlete, so I'm just not going to move at all...

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: ...Which I think is a shame because, again, you don't have to be an athlete to move your body. And so this idea of physical identity is just seeing yourself as a creature that moves and it has a vitality. Being a person with a physical identity doesn't mean I have to play a sport. Like, you can move your body doing other activities. You can do yoga. You can take walks. You can do all sorts of things.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Totally. You also suggest that people pick a physical activity they enjoy because that's what they're going to keep doing.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: How do you actually find it, though?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: I always say, if you haven't found the physical activity that you enjoy, you haven't tried it yet. Take classes. Watch a YouTube video. There's a physical activity or a physical practice out there that you're going to love.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah. I learned that this summer with softball. I had never really played before.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Oh, wow.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: And work was doing some games. Like, NPR does a media league very casually.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: And I just - I showed up. I played second base. I loved it. Now I've played 12 games this year. I'm in like...

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: That's awesome.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: I joined another league. I'm really into it. Who would have thought?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yeah. So yeah, take the Jujitsu class that you've kind of had that hunch, maybe I should try it. Like, just follow that hunch and give it a go. And, you know, worst-case scenario, you're out an hour of your time.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: OK, men, and everyone really, Takeaway 1 - don't forget that you have a physical identity, whether you were good at sports in high school or not, whether you like them now or not. There are so many ways to move your body that you might not have considered. Go for hikes. Run around after your dog or your friend's dog. Try live-action role-play, also known as LARPing. Go rock climbing or bouldering. Try geocaching, which is basically an outdoor treasure hunt. Throw around a Frisbee or play my favorite impromptu game at the office, tossing a highlighter to a friend while standing on one foot. If your office is chill and it's the end of the day, do a desk chair race. Go ice skating or snowshoeing, play paintball or laser tag, climb a tree, dig a hole in the sand.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: OK. So another episode of yours that we loved is about muscle power and explosiveness. What do we mean by that?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: So muscle power is strength expressed quickly. So you use muscle power whenever you sprint, whenever you jump, whenever you skip or whenever you're about to fall down and you have to try to catch yourself before you hit the ground.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: And we tend to lose muscle power or explosiveness as we age, right?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: That's correct. Between the ages of 65 and 90, like, on average, people lose about 3.5% of their muscle power per year.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: OK.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: So it drops off faster than strength. And the reason why it drops off so fast is that we just don't use it. And the thing with muscle power is your nervous system is also involved. And so in order for you to express power, you also have to train that in your nervous system, right? And so if your nervous system isn't used to contracting your muscles as quickly as possible, you're going to lose that ability.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah. And then when you need it, when you need to run really fast 'cause...

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: ...Somebody's chasing you or for whatever reason, to catch the bus, then you pull a hammy.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Right. You pull a hammy or you just don't have that oomph.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: A common one, like, why it's really important for particularly older people - right? - in their 60s or 70s, you use muscle power. It's one of the things you do to catch yourself when you're falling.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah. OK. Well, how can we hold onto our muscle power? How can we get it back?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: There's easy things you can do. Jumping rope is actually a great way to train your lower body muscle power 'cause you're just hopping up and down quickly. You can do squat jumps. So you go down to a squat position, and then when you get to the bottom, you're going to explode out of there and jump as high as you can. Just, like, do two sets of five before your usual workout. You can do more sprinting. Play a - take up a sport where you have to express power. I think softball is a great example of that. You can do medicine ball slams. So just get a...

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: ...Medicine ball that your gym might have and just throw it on the ground as hard as you can. You can do plyometric pushups. So it's - you just do a regular pushup. You're just going to explode up until your hands come a little bit off the ground.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: I've been doing stuff like that. It feels good.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: It does.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: 'Cause you can start to feel the difference.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Takeaway 2 - muscle power, also called explosiveness, allows us to express our strength quickly. It helps us run, jump and catch ourselves so we don't fall over. And we lose it when we don't use it, especially as we age. Some ways to hold on to it - jump rope, squat jumps, plyometric pushups, medicine ball snaps and sports that require throwing and hitting.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: OK, so next up, let's talk about testosterone. You did an episode on this. For men, what does it mean to have a healthy level of testosterone?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: So testosterone is important for men and women. So it's important for bone density. It's important for muscle mass, strength. It's important for sexual health, so libido and sexual function. Mood - testosterone plays a big role in mood in men.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: OK. And should men be getting tested for their testosterone levels regularly, or how does that - how do you go about finding this out anyway?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: So you want to see if you have low symptoms of testosterone. So that - those common low symptoms are low or no libido, erectile dysfunction. You aren't sleeping well, low mood, fatigued, like you - after a workout, it takes you a couple days to recover from a hard workout - brain fog. If you have those symptoms, then you would want to go to talk to your doctor about getting a testosterone test.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Because, like, what happens is - let's say you're a 35-year-old guy. You're feeling good. Libido is great. You recover well from workouts. And you're scrolling Instagram, and you see an ad for, like, oh, get your testosterone tested. Know your number. You're like, oh, OK, I want to go do that. And you do it. And you get the test back, and it shows that your total testosterone - it's on the low end. But this guy, he feels great. Like, he has no symptoms of low testosterone. If he saw that test, he's like, oh, it's low, I must get on TRT then. Like, well, no. Like, how are your symptoms? How are you feeling?

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah. Maybe that's normal for you.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: That's normal for you.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Maybe this is what your body needs, yeah.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Exactly. Exactly. There's a saying in the medical field - you want to treat the patient, not the number. And I feel like what a lot of consumers do who are doing these blood tests on their own, like, they're treating the number instead of themselves.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: OK. Yeah. And what are some of the common treatments for low testosterone?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: A good doctor will first start off with lifestyle interventions.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: So if you have symptoms of low testosterone, they're going to look at your lifestyle and ask you, OK, are you exercising regularly? No. Well, you need to start doing that. Are you overweight? Yes. OK, well, we need to lose some weight because body fat aromatizes testosterone into estrogen. It's a fancy way of saying converts into estrogen, so it can actually reduce your testosterone but increase your estrogen levels. They're going to look at - how's your sleep? Are you sleeping well? No, I'm not. OK. Let's work on your sleep. So I would say, like, doing lifestyle interventions, like pulling those big levers of health first. Try that. And then if not, then you can talk to your doctor about potentially doing hormone replacement therapy.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Takeaway 3 - if you're having symptoms like low libido, erectile dysfunction, low mood, long-lasting fatigue after a workout, brain fog or bad sleep, talk to your doctor. They may recommend a testosterone test, among other things.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: I think one thing that you point out in your reporting on this is that it's not just about testosterone.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Like, you also want your testosterone to be in balance with the other hormones in your body.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yeah. So hormones - man, you can get so in the weeds with this stuff because hormones are incredibly complex 'cause you also think about estrogen. Men also have estrogen. It's important for their health. It's important for heart health. It's also important hormone in libido and sexual health. And so if estrogen gets too low, well, that's not good. But then if it gets too high, well, that's not good either. I mean, so I think that's why once you - if you're looking at hormone replacement therapy, you got to have a doctor. I would have someone who's an expert on this stuff guiding you through this because as you start introducing exogenous testosterone into your body, like, these other hormonal systems are also going to be affected, and you have to, like, keep an eye on that as well.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: After the break, we'll have more men's health tips from Brett McKay.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: All right. We're back with Brett McKay, host of "The Art Of Manliness." Let's shift a little bit and talk about mental health. You have written about depression, your personal experience with it, and also what the latest research says. What have you found about how depression tends to manifest in men specifically?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Oftentimes, depression in men can show up as anger or irritability or alcoholism or workaholism. Like, they spend more time working. And so that's why depression and men often gets overlooked.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah. And I feel like it can be harder to talk about. If you're a man, it might be less accepted.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yeah. Yeah, you're supposed to have your stuff together. And also I think a lot of guys, they just - I think even a lot of people, not just - this is not just a guy problem. A lot of people just don't even know the emotions that they're experiencing.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: They don't know how to label it. Like, they feel the thing, but they don't know what it is. So they can't talk about it.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah. Well, you learned some research-backed tips on how men can manage their depression. Can you share a few of those?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yeah. So the big one is exercise, physical exercise. The research suggests that it is as effective as antidepressants and talk therapy. It's amazing. It does so much, not only for physical health, but for our mental health as well.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: So, you know, I say, if you're a guy struggling with depression, like, start exercising. Like, it's one of the best things you can do. Socializing is another one that can help out a lot. Just being around people, talking with them, can do a lot of things to help alleviate your depressive symptoms. Getting enough sleep is an important one. Eating a nutritious diet is important. If you just do the things that you do to be a healthy person, like, it's going to help you manage your depression as well.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah. Is there anything that you would share from your own experience with it?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yeah. I mean, I've had depression. I've had some severe moments of it, but, you know, kind of just dealing with a general melancholy for most of my adult life. And I think the thing that helped me the most is I stopped looking at my depression or my melancholy as this thing I have to fix. That can cause a lot of frustration in people 'cause they like, I'm sad. I need to be happy. So I'm going to do all these things to quit being sad and being happy all the time. That's never going to happen. Like, there's no silver bullet for curing your depression. Like, it's...

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: ...Going to be part of your life. And how can it be part of your life so that it doesn't get in the way of you living a flourishing life? And I also think just resetting your expectations about happiness. I think in America, we have this idea of happiness being like, you're in this chipper, good mood all the time.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: But going back to my love of classical culture, like, the ancient Greeks had their - their idea of happiness was eudaimonia or just flourishing. It's like just living a good life. And you can do that, even though you might not feel super ecstatic all the time. Like, you can have good relationships. You can do good work. You can be involved in your community, even if you don't feel the best. And, yeah, by changing those expectations, like, I'm just - like, I'm less hard on myself. And so whenever I'm feeling, like, OK, something - I'm kind of going to, like, a not great place, I just do the things I know that'll make me feel better - exercise, get together with some friends, go sit in the sauna.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Or go sit in the sun.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Oh, man, the sun. Sun can help out a lot.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Takeaway 4 - depression doesn't always look like sadness. For some men, it might look like anger or aggression, working too much or engaging in risky behaviors. Research shows that regular exercise can be as effective in treating depression as antidepressants or talk therapy, but this doesn't have to be either/or. Exercise alongside medication and cognitive behavioral therapy leads to even better outcomes. Having positive social experiences might also help and so can eating a healthy diet. A Mediterranean diet has been linked to lower rates of depression. But depression and treating it can look different for everybody. If you're dealing with it, talk to your doctor about what treatments make sense for you.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Sort of along these lines, like, you talked about the importance of socializing, getting outside and talking to other people can really lift your mood. And you actually have an episode about what you call the good stress of socializing. What do you mean that it's a good stress?

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yeah. So this is with Jeffrey Hall. He's a professor at the University of Kansas who studies friendships and communication. And he talks about the health benefits that come from socializing, right? It can help reduce your dementia. It can help reduce mild cognitive decline. It can help with mood, like depression or anxiety. It can even help our physical health. People who have strong social ties - they tend to get sick less. And it's like, well, why is that? Why is socializing so good for our mental and physical health? And Jeffrey talks about how it's basically socializing helps reduce chronic stress, which makes sense. We're designed to go to the group whenever we're stressed out, so we can just be like, oh, my gosh, I'm feeling really bad right now, but I'm with these other people. It feels good to be with these people. Like, they got my back. We're all in this together. That feels good. But the thing about socializing that Jeffrey points out is that socializing itself can be stressful.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: And why is socializing stressful? Well, people can be awful sometimes, right? You're having a conversation with someone, and someone says something really rude or inappropriate, people misunderstand you. There's awkward silences. You don't know where the conversation is going to go. And also just, like, planning to socialize can be stressful. And because it's so stressful and there's so much friction, oftentimes, we decide, You know what? I'm just going to stay in this weekend. I'm not going to do anything. I'm just going to watch Netflix. So socializing is this weird thing. So it reduces chronic stress in the long term. But in the short term, it causes stress. And Jeffrey makes the analogy to exercise 'cause exercise is kind of the same thing.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: So in the long term, it reduces stress, it reduces inflammation. But in the short term, exercise is unpleasant and actually increases inflammation. And so exercise is a - what we call a hormetic stressor, a good stressor. You need to do a little bit of it, that acute stress, to get the benefits of the reduction in chronic stress. Same thing with socializing.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: It feels like getting the reps in.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yeah. I think that's a great - like the idea of doing reps. I start seeing my chances to socialize as little mini workouts, like, or reps. Like, oh, here's a chance to exercise my socialization muscle.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Takeaway 5 - take advantage of the good stress of socializing. Yes, it can feel stressful in the moment, but it can also lower your levels of stress in the long term.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: I started a monthly dinner with a small group of friends, and we've just done our first one. We're about to do our second one. But the point for me was really to ground my community 'cause I have community, but, like, I wanted to ground it in routine.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yeah. I think it's a great idea of having this standing (ph) thing. I mean, one of the big things that get in the way of people actually getting together with people is, like, you spend so much time in those group chats where you're trying to coordinate schedules. And so you just have to accept the fact that not everyone's going to be able to come.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: But just say, look, here - when we're doing it, we're always going to do it this time at this place. If you can make it, fantastic. If not, we'll love to have you the next time. I've had these standing sort of things with some groups that I've done. Like, I was part of a book club of just a bunch of guys here in town, and the event was every other week on Thursday night at 8 o'clock. And it's like, well, you can make it - fantastic. If not, that's OK.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: See you next time.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Brett McKay, thank you so much for coming on the show.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: Well, thanks for having me. This has been an absolute pleasure. It was so much fun.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Yes. Let's do it again sometime.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: OK, time for a recap. Takeaway 1 - don't forget that you have a physical identity, whether you were good at sports in high school or not, whether you like them now or not. Try out some new ways of moving your body and find out what you like. Takeaway 2 - muscle power can help us run, jump and catch ourselves so we don't fall over, and we lose it when we don't use it, especially as we age. Some ways to hold onto it are to jump rope, do squat jumps, do plyometric push-ups, do medicine ball snaps and play sports that require throwing and hitting. Takeaway 3 - if you're having symptoms like low libido, erectile dysfunction, low mood, long-lasting fatigue after working out, brain fog and bad sleep, talk to your doctor. They might recommend a testosterone test, and they'll likely start by suggesting lifestyle changes before they recommend any kind of hormone replacement therapy.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: Takeaway 4 - research shows that regular exercise is as effective in treating depression as antidepressants or talk therapy. Having positive social experiences can also help and so can eating a healthy diet. But depression and treating it can look different for everyone. So if you're dealing with it, talk to your doctor about all your treatment options. Takeaway 5 - take advantage of the good stress of socializing. Yes, it can feel stressful in the moment, especially when you have to plan, but it can lower your levels of stress in the long term. Oh, one more tip from Brett about facial hair - try a scented beard oil.

transcript.author: MCKAY
transcript.text: I do like to do it during Christmastime 'cause there's beard oils that smell like Christmas trees or cinnamon. And it's just nice to have, like, you know, during December, you're working and you're like, oh, it smells like the Polar Express.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: And that's our show. Before we go, I have a favor to ask - if you have a moment, would you leave LIFE KIT a five-star rating on your podcast app? If LIFE KIT has ever helped you save a little money or make a healthier choice for yourself, a five-star rating is a great way to show your support. Thank you so much.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: This episode of LIFE KIT was produced by Margaret Cirino. Our visuals editor is Beck Harlan, and our digital editor is Malaka Gharib. Meghan Keane is our senior supervising editor, and Beth Donovan is our executive producer. Our production team also includes Andee Tagle, Clare Marie Schneider and Sylvie Douglis. Engineering support comes from Robert Rodriguez and Cena Loffredo. Fact-checking by Tyler Jones.

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: I'm Marielle Segarra. Thanks for listening.

lines: You're listening to LIFE KIT...
...From NPR.
Hey. It's Marielle. Brett McKay has an impressive mustache.

It looks like the head of a broom - black, maybe a little salt and pepper and, to my eye, an indispensable companion to his eyebrows. He first grew it out for Movember in 2009. That's the annual campaign in November where folks sport mustaches to raise awareness and money for men's health.

I didn't think I was going to keep it. But at the end of Movember, I was like, you know what? I actually look pretty good in this. And my wife was like, I'm really surprised by this, but I also think you look good in it, too.

Brett is the writer of a blog and the host of a podcast called "The Art Of Manliness." So of course, I had to ask, what does manliness mean to him? He said he studied classical literature in college, things like the "Iliad" and the writings of Cicero. And that word, manliness, meant something different then than it often does today.

I think today, we have this sort of cartoonish idea of what manliness is. It's this big, burly guy who likes to eat meat and lift weights. But for ancient Greeks and ancient Romans - and you can see this all the way up through the 19th century in the West - to be manly meant the development of certain virtues, like prudence and courage and strength. And so it's about becoming a virtuous, all-around solid dude. And I wanted to bring that idea back that manliness could be something that's positive and affirming.

"The Art Of Manliness" actually reminds me a lot of LIFE KIT. Brett interviews experts on different topics, including health, but the show is made specifically for men, and they give tips on all sorts of topics, including growing facial hair.

One is, don't waste your money on beard serums or vitamins that promise increased beard growth. They're probably not going to do it. A lot of facial hair just comes down to genetics. But the thing you can do for facial hair is just, like, be a healthy person, like, sleep well, eat a nutritious diet, exercise, 'cause that also contributes to hair growth.

On this episode of LIFE KIT, Brett and I talk about men's health. He'll share five takeaways based on the reporting he's done for "The Art Of Manliness" on movement, explosive strength, testosterone, depression and the good stress of socializing. A quick disclaimer here - Brett is not a medical doctor. He's someone who's passionate about his health and about sharing the research out there. If you do have any questions about these topics, for sure bring them up with your doctor.
You have an episode on how men, and everyone really, can nurture their physical identity. So what does that mean, physical identity?

So we are moving creatures, right? When we're a baby, we learn how to crawl. Eventually, we learn how to walk, and then when we're kids, we run and play. The problem is you develop this idea when you're a kid - it's like, you're either an athlete or you're not an athlete.
Yeah.

I'm sure everyone remembers when they were in elementary school or middle school getting picked last for the dodgeball team, playing Little League baseball and just realizing, oh, I'm not good at this. And so what happens is when you're a kid, you're like, well, I'm not an athlete, so I'm just not going to move at all...
Yeah.

...Which I think is a shame because, again, you don't have to be an athlete to move your body. And so this idea of physical identity is just seeing yourself as a creature that moves and it has a vitality. Being a person with a physical identity doesn't mean I have to play a sport. Like, you can move your body doing other activities. You can do yoga. You can take walks. You can do all sorts of things.
Totally. You also suggest that people pick a physical activity they enjoy because that's what they're going to keep doing.
Yes.
How do you actually find it, though?

I always say, if you haven't found the physical activity that you enjoy, you haven't tried it yet. Take classes. Watch a YouTube video. There's a physical activity or a physical practice out there that you're going to love.
Yeah. I learned that this summer with softball. I had never really played before.
Oh, wow.
And work was doing some games. Like, NPR does a media league very casually.
Yeah.
And I just - I showed up. I played second base. I loved it. Now I've played 12 games this year. I'm in like...
That's awesome.
I joined another league. I'm really into it. Who would have thought?

Yeah. So yeah, take the Jujitsu class that you've kind of had that hunch, maybe I should try it. Like, just follow that hunch and give it a go. And, you know, worst-case scenario, you're out an hour of your time.

OK, men, and everyone really, Takeaway 1 - don't forget that you have a physical identity, whether you were good at sports in high school or not, whether you like them now or not. There are so many ways to move your body that you might not have considered. Go for hikes. Run around after your dog or your friend's dog. Try live-action role-play, also known as LARPing. Go rock climbing or bouldering. Try geocaching, which is basically an outdoor treasure hunt. Throw around a Frisbee or play my favorite impromptu game at the office, tossing a highlighter to a friend while standing on one foot. If your office is chill and it's the end of the day, do a desk chair race. Go ice skating or snowshoeing, play paintball or laser tag, climb a tree, dig a hole in the sand.
OK. So another episode of yours that we loved is about muscle power and explosiveness. What do we mean by that?

So muscle power is strength expressed quickly. So you use muscle power whenever you sprint, whenever you jump, whenever you skip or whenever you're about to fall down and you have to try to catch yourself before you hit the ground.
And we tend to lose muscle power or explosiveness as we age, right?
That's correct. Between the ages of 65 and 90, like, on average, people lose about 3.5% of their muscle power per year.
OK.

So it drops off faster than strength. And the reason why it drops off so fast is that we just don't use it. And the thing with muscle power is your nervous system is also involved. And so in order for you to express power, you also have to train that in your nervous system, right? And so if your nervous system isn't used to contracting your muscles as quickly as possible, you're going to lose that ability.
Yeah. And then when you need it, when you need to run really fast 'cause...
Yeah.
...Somebody's chasing you or for whatever reason, to catch the bus, then you pull a hammy.
Right. You pull a hammy or you just don't have that oomph.
Yeah.
A common one, like, why it's really important for particularly older people - right? - in their 60s or 70s, you use muscle power. It's one of the things you do to catch yourself when you're falling.
Yeah. OK. Well, how can we hold onto our muscle power? How can we get it back?

There's easy things you can do. Jumping rope is actually a great way to train your lower body muscle power 'cause you're just hopping up and down quickly. You can do squat jumps. So you go down to a squat position, and then when you get to the bottom, you're going to explode out of there and jump as high as you can. Just, like, do two sets of five before your usual workout. You can do more sprinting. Play a - take up a sport where you have to express power. I think softball is a great example of that. You can do medicine ball slams. So just get a...
Yeah.

...Medicine ball that your gym might have and just throw it on the ground as hard as you can. You can do plyometric pushups. So it's - you just do a regular pushup. You're just going to explode up until your hands come a little bit off the ground.
I've been doing stuff like that. It feels good.
It does.
'Cause you can start to feel the difference.
That's right.

Takeaway 2 - muscle power, also called explosiveness, allows us to express our strength quickly. It helps us run, jump and catch ourselves so we don't fall over. And we lose it when we don't use it, especially as we age. Some ways to hold on to it - jump rope, squat jumps, plyometric pushups, medicine ball snaps and sports that require throwing and hitting.
OK, so next up, let's talk about testosterone. You did an episode on this. For men, what does it mean to have a healthy level of testosterone?

So testosterone is important for men and women. So it's important for bone density. It's important for muscle mass, strength. It's important for sexual health, so libido and sexual function. Mood - testosterone plays a big role in mood in men.
OK. And should men be getting tested for their testosterone levels regularly, or how does that - how do you go about finding this out anyway?

So you want to see if you have low symptoms of testosterone. So that - those common low symptoms are low or no libido, erectile dysfunction. You aren't sleeping well, low mood, fatigued, like you - after a workout, it takes you a couple days to recover from a hard workout - brain fog. If you have those symptoms, then you would want to go to talk to your doctor about getting a testosterone test.

Because, like, what happens is - let's say you're a 35-year-old guy. You're feeling good. Libido is great. You recover well from workouts. And you're scrolling Instagram, and you see an ad for, like, oh, get your testosterone tested. Know your number. You're like, oh, OK, I want to go do that. And you do it. And you get the test back, and it shows that your total testosterone - it's on the low end. But this guy, he feels great. Like, he has no symptoms of low testosterone. If he saw that test, he's like, oh, it's low, I must get on TRT then. Like, well, no. Like, how are your symptoms? How are you feeling?
Yeah. Maybe that's normal for you.
That's normal for you.
Maybe this is what your body needs, yeah.

Exactly. Exactly. There's a saying in the medical field - you want to treat the patient, not the number. And I feel like what a lot of consumers do who are doing these blood tests on their own, like, they're treating the number instead of themselves.
OK. Yeah. And what are some of the common treatments for low testosterone?
A good doctor will first start off with lifestyle interventions.
Yeah.

So if you have symptoms of low testosterone, they're going to look at your lifestyle and ask you, OK, are you exercising regularly? No. Well, you need to start doing that. Are you overweight? Yes. OK, well, we need to lose some weight because body fat aromatizes testosterone into estrogen. It's a fancy way of saying converts into estrogen, so it can actually reduce your testosterone but increase your estrogen levels. They're going to look at - how's your sleep? Are you sleeping well? No, I'm not. OK. Let's work on your sleep. So I would say, like, doing lifestyle interventions, like pulling those big levers of health first. Try that. And then if not, then you can talk to your doctor about potentially doing hormone replacement therapy.

Takeaway 3 - if you're having symptoms like low libido, erectile dysfunction, low mood, long-lasting fatigue after a workout, brain fog or bad sleep, talk to your doctor. They may recommend a testosterone test, among other things.
I think one thing that you point out in your reporting on this is that it's not just about testosterone.
Yeah.
Like, you also want your testosterone to be in balance with the other hormones in your body.

Yeah. So hormones - man, you can get so in the weeds with this stuff because hormones are incredibly complex 'cause you also think about estrogen. Men also have estrogen. It's important for their health. It's important for heart health. It's also important hormone in libido and sexual health. And so if estrogen gets too low, well, that's not good. But then if it gets too high, well, that's not good either. I mean, so I think that's why once you - if you're looking at hormone replacement therapy, you got to have a doctor. I would have someone who's an expert on this stuff guiding you through this because as you start introducing exogenous testosterone into your body, like, these other hormonal systems are also going to be affected, and you have to, like, keep an eye on that as well.
After the break, we'll have more men's health tips from Brett McKay.

All right. We're back with Brett McKay, host of "The Art Of Manliness." Let's shift a little bit and talk about mental health. You have written about depression, your personal experience with it, and also what the latest research says. What have you found about how depression tends to manifest in men specifically?
Oftentimes, depression in men can show up as anger or irritability or alcoholism or workaholism. Like, they spend more time working. And so that's why depression and men often gets overlooked.
Yeah. And I feel like it can be harder to talk about. If you're a man, it might be less accepted.

Yeah. Yeah, you're supposed to have your stuff together. And also I think a lot of guys, they just - I think even a lot of people, not just - this is not just a guy problem. A lot of people just don't even know the emotions that they're experiencing.
Yeah.
They don't know how to label it. Like, they feel the thing, but they don't know what it is. So they can't talk about it.
Yeah. Well, you learned some research-backed tips on how men can manage their depression. Can you share a few of those?

Yeah. So the big one is exercise, physical exercise. The research suggests that it is as effective as antidepressants and talk therapy. It's amazing. It does so much, not only for physical health, but for our mental health as well.
Yes.

So, you know, I say, if you're a guy struggling with depression, like, start exercising. Like, it's one of the best things you can do. Socializing is another one that can help out a lot. Just being around people, talking with them, can do a lot of things to help alleviate your depressive symptoms. Getting enough sleep is an important one. Eating a nutritious diet is important. If you just do the things that you do to be a healthy person, like, it's going to help you manage your depression as well.
Yeah. Is there anything that you would share from your own experience with it?

Yeah. I mean, I've had depression. I've had some severe moments of it, but, you know, kind of just dealing with a general melancholy for most of my adult life. And I think the thing that helped me the most is I stopped looking at my depression or my melancholy as this thing I have to fix. That can cause a lot of frustration in people 'cause they like, I'm sad. I need to be happy. So I'm going to do all these things to quit being sad and being happy all the time. That's never going to happen. Like, there's no silver bullet for curing your depression. Like, it's...
Yeah.

...Going to be part of your life. And how can it be part of your life so that it doesn't get in the way of you living a flourishing life? And I also think just resetting your expectations about happiness. I think in America, we have this idea of happiness being like, you're in this chipper, good mood all the time.
Yeah.

But going back to my love of classical culture, like, the ancient Greeks had their - their idea of happiness was eudaimonia or just flourishing. It's like just living a good life. And you can do that, even though you might not feel super ecstatic all the time. Like, you can have good relationships. You can do good work. You can be involved in your community, even if you don't feel the best. And, yeah, by changing those expectations, like, I'm just - like, I'm less hard on myself. And so whenever I'm feeling, like, OK, something - I'm kind of going to, like, a not great place, I just do the things I know that'll make me feel better - exercise, get together with some friends, go sit in the sauna.
Or go sit in the sun.
Oh, man, the sun. Sun can help out a lot.

Takeaway 4 - depression doesn't always look like sadness. For some men, it might look like anger or aggression, working too much or engaging in risky behaviors. Research shows that regular exercise can be as effective in treating depression as antidepressants or talk therapy, but this doesn't have to be either/or. Exercise alongside medication and cognitive behavioral therapy leads to even better outcomes. Having positive social experiences might also help and so can eating a healthy diet. A Mediterranean diet has been linked to lower rates of depression. But depression and treating it can look different for everybody. If you're dealing with it, talk to your doctor about what treatments make sense for you.

Sort of along these lines, like, you talked about the importance of socializing, getting outside and talking to other people can really lift your mood. And you actually have an episode about what you call the good stress of socializing. What do you mean that it's a good stress?

Yeah. So this is with Jeffrey Hall. He's a professor at the University of Kansas who studies friendships and communication. And he talks about the health benefits that come from socializing, right? It can help reduce your dementia. It can help reduce mild cognitive decline. It can help with mood, like depression or anxiety. It can even help our physical health. People who have strong social ties - they tend to get sick less. And it's like, well, why is that? Why is socializing so good for our mental and physical health? And Jeffrey talks about how it's basically socializing helps reduce chronic stress, which makes sense. We're designed to go to the group whenever we're stressed out, so we can just be like, oh, my gosh, I'm feeling really bad right now, but I'm with these other people. It feels good to be with these people. Like, they got my back. We're all in this together. That feels good. But the thing about socializing that Jeffrey points out is that socializing itself can be stressful.
Yeah.

And why is socializing stressful? Well, people can be awful sometimes, right? You're having a conversation with someone, and someone says something really rude or inappropriate, people misunderstand you. There's awkward silences. You don't know where the conversation is going to go. And also just, like, planning to socialize can be stressful. And because it's so stressful and there's so much friction, oftentimes, we decide, You know what? I'm just going to stay in this weekend. I'm not going to do anything. I'm just going to watch Netflix. So socializing is this weird thing. So it reduces chronic stress in the long term. But in the short term, it causes stress. And Jeffrey makes the analogy to exercise 'cause exercise is kind of the same thing.
Yeah.

So in the long term, it reduces stress, it reduces inflammation. But in the short term, exercise is unpleasant and actually increases inflammation. And so exercise is a - what we call a hormetic stressor, a good stressor. You need to do a little bit of it, that acute stress, to get the benefits of the reduction in chronic stress. Same thing with socializing.
It feels like getting the reps in.

Yeah. I think that's a great - like the idea of doing reps. I start seeing my chances to socialize as little mini workouts, like, or reps. Like, oh, here's a chance to exercise my socialization muscle.
Takeaway 5 - take advantage of the good stress of socializing. Yes, it can feel stressful in the moment, but it can also lower your levels of stress in the long term.

I started a monthly dinner with a small group of friends, and we've just done our first one. We're about to do our second one. But the point for me was really to ground my community 'cause I have community, but, like, I wanted to ground it in routine.

Yeah. I think it's a great idea of having this standing (ph) thing. I mean, one of the big things that get in the way of people actually getting together with people is, like, you spend so much time in those group chats where you're trying to coordinate schedules. And so you just have to accept the fact that not everyone's going to be able to come.
Yeah.

But just say, look, here - when we're doing it, we're always going to do it this time at this place. If you can make it, fantastic. If not, we'll love to have you the next time. I've had these standing sort of things with some groups that I've done. Like, I was part of a book club of just a bunch of guys here in town, and the event was every other week on Thursday night at 8 o'clock. And it's like, well, you can make it - fantastic. If not, that's OK.
See you next time.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Brett McKay, thank you so much for coming on the show.
Well, thanks for having me. This has been an absolute pleasure. It was so much fun.
Yes. Let's do it again sometime.

OK, time for a recap. Takeaway 1 - don't forget that you have a physical identity, whether you were good at sports in high school or not, whether you like them now or not. Try out some new ways of moving your body and find out what you like. Takeaway 2 - muscle power can help us run, jump and catch ourselves so we don't fall over, and we lose it when we don't use it, especially as we age. Some ways to hold onto it are to jump rope, do squat jumps, do plyometric push-ups, do medicine ball snaps and play sports that require throwing and hitting. Takeaway 3 - if you're having symptoms like low libido, erectile dysfunction, low mood, long-lasting fatigue after working out, brain fog and bad sleep, talk to your doctor. They might recommend a testosterone test, and they'll likely start by suggesting lifestyle changes before they recommend any kind of hormone replacement therapy.

Takeaway 4 - research shows that regular exercise is as effective in treating depression as antidepressants or talk therapy. Having positive social experiences can also help and so can eating a healthy diet. But depression and treating it can look different for everyone. So if you're dealing with it, talk to your doctor about all your treatment options. Takeaway 5 - take advantage of the good stress of socializing. Yes, it can feel stressful in the moment, especially when you have to plan, but it can lower your levels of stress in the long term. Oh, one more tip from Brett about facial hair - try a scented beard oil.

I do like to do it during Christmastime 'cause there's beard oils that smell like Christmas trees or cinnamon. And it's just nice to have, like, you know, during December, you're working and you're like, oh, it smells like the Polar Express.

And that's our show. Before we go, I have a favor to ask - if you have a moment, would you leave LIFE KIT a five-star rating on your podcast app? If LIFE KIT has ever helped you save a little money or make a healthier choice for yourself, a five-star rating is a great way to show your support. Thank you so much.

Meghan Keane is our senior supervising editor, and Beth Donovan is our executive producer. Our production team also includes Andee Tagle, Clare Marie Schneider and Sylvie Douglis. I'm Marielle Segarra. Thanks for listening.
